subject: RE: [junit] use of setUp and tearDown
msgSnippet: ... You can see it any way you want, I am just saying that it s not very useful to read 101 FAILURES as opposed to 1 FAILURE, 100 SKIPS . And as I was
messageBody:
> From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On

> I see setUp just as a programmatical way to remove
> duplication, not as a separate entity.

You can see it any way you want, I am just saying that it's not very useful
to read "101 FAILURES" as opposed to "1 FAILURE, 100 SKIPS".

And as I was saying earlier, you are probably so used to JUnit that when you
read "101 FAILURES", you just *know* that it's not true that 101 tests
failed. You know that only one of them failed (maybe a setUp or another
test) and all the other ones are failing in cascade.

And you also know that you probably only need to fix *1* test to come back
to "101 SUCCESSES".

Now, wouldn't it be nice if the testing framework told you exactly *which*
test you should look at first?

> 100 failures, and when I look at the stack trace it's
> immediately clear where the problem actually is.

You shouldn't have to look at a stack trace, the testing framework should
tell you right away which of the 101 FAILURES is the "real" one.

> > Compare this to "1 FAILURE, 100 SKIPS".
> >
> > Now, *that* is a much more acurate view of what really happened.
>
> As I said, setUp and test method are one in my view of a test results.
> But that may be due to I'm used to JUnit's way of handling this.

That's also my impression. Just trying to shake out your perception :-)

> So, assuming I don't check in code with non-green tests, why
> is it important to distinguish between skipped and failed tests?
> Doesn't a skip turn the bar red?

With TestNG, they are yellow :-)

It's important to distinguish between SKIPPED and FAILED because it gives
you a list of tests to look at in the right order. TestNG lists them as
follows:

- Failed tests (red)
- Skipped tests (yellow)
- Passed tests (green)

Star fixing the failed tests and when you are done, it's quite likely that
the skipped tests will pass and you'll be done.
